Calm and chaos at Il Lombardia

To the surprise of absolutely nobody, Tadej Pogaƒçar rode to victory at Il Lombardia with a 48km solo attack. He became only the second man in history to win in four consecutive years, the only other being Fausto Coppi between 1946 and 1949.

The Slovenian attacked on the Colma di Sormano climb and no one could follow. After crossing the finish line, he had plenty of time ‚Äì over three minutes ‚Äì to climb off his bike and raise it over his head in celebration before the arrival of second place Remco Evenepoel. Further back still, Giulio Ciccone jumped away from his group to claim the final podium spot.

This win marks Pogaƒçar‚Äôs 25th of the season, but his domination wasn‚Äôt the only talking point surrounding the race. Before the race, Tom Pidcock revealed he had been ‚Äòdeselected‚Äô while on the team bus to Lombardy despite his second place behind Pogaƒçar at Giro dell‚ÄôEmilia the week prior.

Teammate Geraint Thomas later said on his podcast, ‚ÄòHe‚Äôs not happy. The team‚Äôs not happy. How has it got to this point? I don‚Äôt know‚Ä¶ People who are around Tom I don‚Äôt think help.‚Äô

Rumours have been swirling that Pidcock could be departing Ineos Grenadiers this offseason. The team‚Äôs best-placed rider at Il Lombardia was Thymen Arensman in 15th.

Zoe B√§ckstedt impresses at Simac Ladies Tour

Zoe B√§ckstedt was a fighting force at the six-day Simac Ladies Tour. She won the opening stage individual time-trial and wore the yellow leader‚Äôs jersey but was left without any teammates by the end of Stage 2.

Chlo√© Dygert broke her nose on the hotel bathroom door while roommates Maike van der Duin and Soraya Paladin both withdrew through illness. Finally Alex Morrice was caught out early on Stage 2 and abandoned.

Despite having four stages still to go, B√§ckstedt persevered. She was only overtaken on the general classification after Stage 4 by DSM‚Äôs Franziska Koch. At the end of the race, she sat third on GC behind winner Lotte Kopecky and Koch and was also the best young rider.

Racing alone is no issue for the 20-year-old, who is the current U23 World and European cyclocross champion.

Belgian Champion Eli Iserbyt was disqualified from Exact Cross Beringen this weekend after deliberately stamping on Ryan Kamp‚Äôs bike.

Video footage circulated online that showed Iserbyt and Kamp crashing on lap five. After picking up his own bike, Iserbyt stomped on Kamp‚Äôs derailleur ‚Äì Kamp then pulled Iserbyt back to exchange some harsh words. On the following lap, Iserbyt was pulled from the race.

Taking to social media, Iserbyt said, ‚ÄòI understand the decision of the jury to DSQ me today in Beringen. My acts after the hard crash were made in a rage of anger and don‚Äôt belong in this sport.‚Äô

I understand the decision of the jury to dsq me today in Beringen. My acts after the hard crash were made in a rage of anger and don‚Äôt belong in this sport. For this I want to apologise to everyone involved. Now I‚Äôll focus on the positivie things and look frwrd to the next races!

Speaking to Sporza, he added, ‚ÄòThis is something that‚Äôs been an issue for previous seasons. He [Kamp] cuts corners more often, and he did it again now.‚Äô

The race was won by Lars van der Haar of Baloise‚ÄìTrek Lions. In the women‚Äôs race, Visma-Lease a Bike‚Äôs Fem van Empel soloed to victory by 42sec.

Velo d‚ÄôOr finalists announced

The finalists for the men and women‚Äôs Velo d‚ÄôOr award ‚Äì given to the best cyclists of the season ‚Äì have been announced, with ten male and ten female nominees. The men‚Äôs category includes riders such as Tadej Pogaƒçar, Mathieu van der Poel, Biniam Girmay, Marc Hirschi and Tim Merlier with Lotte Kopecky, Marianne Vos, Kasia Niewiadoma, Lorena Wiebes and Kristen Faulkner included as five of the ten women nominated.

Other awards include the ‚ÄòEddy Merckx Trophy‚Äô for the best one-day racer as well as the ‚ÄòBernard Hinault Trophy‚Äô for the best French road rider of the season. This year, there is also a new trophy awarded to the best cyclists in Olympics disciplines ‚Äì¬†essentially not road cycling ‚Äì and finalists include Ellesse Andrews, Harrie Lavreysen and Tom Pidcock.

Find the full list at lequipe.fr. The winners will be announced on 6th December.

Retirements aplenty

Multiple riders have retired in the past week. SD Worx-Protime‚Äôs Christine Majerus and Human Powered Health duo Audrey Cordon-Ragot and Alice Wood all retired at the Simac Ladies Tour.

Grace Brown, world and Olympic ITT gold medallist, chose to do so after winning at Chrono des Nations while Domenico Pozzovivo finally hung up his cleats after finishing 38th at Il Lombardia aged 41.
